\begin{Large}
\textbf{S1 Text: Deriving probability of transmission given linkage}
\vspace{10px}
\end{Large}

We begin by defining two matrices containing binary response variables. The first matrix $\mathbf Y$ contains the variable $y_{ij}$, which indicates that case $i$ and case $j$ are linked through a direct transmission event (i.e., case $i$ infected case $j$ or vice versa). Matrix $\mathbf{Y}$ has dimensions $N \times N$, where $N$ is the population (i.e., final outbreak) size. The second matrix $\mathbf{Z}$ contains the variable $z_{ij}$, which indicates inferred linkage between cases $i$ and $j$ based on some phylogenetic criteria. Matrix $\mathbf{Z}$ has dimensions $M \times M$, where $M$ is the sample size and $M \subset N$.

Our aim is to determine the quantity $\Pr (y_{ij} \mid z_{ij})$, which is defined as the probability that case $i$ is linked by transmission to case $j$ (a true transmission pair), given that they have been linked by some phylogenetic criteria. We start by making a number of assumptions that simplify the derivation, and will in turn relax these assumptions to arrive at the equations in the main text.

\appendix

<!-- APPENDIX A: THE SIMPLEST CASE -->

\section{The simplest case}
\label{section:simple}

\subsection{Assumptions}

We make the following simplifying assumptions:
\begin{itemize}
    \item[1.] Each case $i$ is linked by transmission to only one other case $j$ in the population (N).
    \item[2.] Each case $i$ is linked by the linkage criteria to only one other case $j$ in the sampled population (M).
    \item[3.] The sensitivity of the linkage criteria is equal to 1 when both the infector and infectee have been sampled. In other words, if case $i$ is truly linked by transmission to case $j$ and both cases are found in sample $M$, then $y_{ij} = 1$ by definition, and under perfect sensitivity $z_{ij} = 1$ as well.
\end{itemize}

\subsection{Derivation of the probability of transmission given linkage}

Under the assumptions above, we can show that:

\begin{align*} \label{eq:simple_pr}
    \Pr(\y \mid \z) &= \frac{\Pr(\y, \z)}{\Pr(\z)} = \frac{\Pr(\y, \z)}{\Pr(\y, \z) + \Pr(\neg\y, \z)}\\[10pt]
    \intertext{However, we must also account for the uncertainty that, for any sampled case $i$, its true transmission pair is in the sample. So we define define $S_i$ as the probability that the true pair of case $i$ has been sampled from the population $N$ and apply the law of total probability accordingly:}
    &= \frac{
    \cancelto{1}{\Pr(\y, \z\mid S_i)}\Pr(S_i) + \cancelto{0}{\Pr(\y, \z\mid \neg S_i)}\Pr(\neg S_i)
    }{
    \begin{bmatrix}
    \cancelto{1}{\Pr(\y, \z\mid S_i)}\Pr(S_i) + \cancelto{0}{\Pr(\y, \z\mid \neg S_i)}\Pr(\neg S_i) \  + \\
    \cancelto{0}{\Pr(\neg\y, \z\mid S_i)}\Pr(S_i) + \Pr(\neg\y, \z\mid \neg S_i)\Pr(\neg S_i)
    \end{bmatrix}
    }\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{\Pr(S_i)}{\Pr(S_i) + \Pr(\neg\y, \z\mid \neg S_i)\Pr(\neg S_i)}\\[10pt]
    \intertext{We know that $\Pr(S_i)$ is equal to the sampling fraction \big($\frac{M}{N}$\big),
    which we define as $\rho$:}
    &= \frac{\rho}{\rho + \Pr(\neg\y, \z\mid \neg S_i)(1-\rho)}\\[10pt]
    \intertext{The term $\Pr(\neg\y, \z\mid \neg S_i)$ is the probability that case $i$ is linked to case $j$ 
    when $i$ is not the true pair of $j$ and the true pair of $j$ is not in the sample $M$. Given our assumption that each case is linked to exactly one other case by the phylogenetic criteria, the probability of this (incorrect) link between cases $i$ and $j$ is equal the probability that the remaining $M-1$ other possible (incorrect) links do not occur, which can be written as $(1-\chi^{M-1})$, where $\chi$ is the specificity of the linkage criteria:}
    &= \frac{\rho}{\rho + (1-\chi^{M-1})(1-\rho)}\\[10pt]
    \intertext{\textbf{Therefore, the probability of transmission given linkage assuming perfect sensitivity, 
    single transmission, and single linkage is:}}
    \Pr(\y \mid \z) &= \frac{\rho}{\rho + (1-\chi^{M-1})(1-\rho)}
    \stepcounter{equation}\tag{\theequation}\\[10pt]
\end{align*}

The probability spaces in Equation \ref{eq:simple_pr} above can also be represented by the conceptual diagram shown below:

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{../Figures/S1Text_Fig1.png}
\end{center}

\subsection{Calculating the expected number of pairs in the sample}
Given the number of pairs identified from the linkage criteria, the expected number of those pairs that represent true transmission pairs is:
$$
\mathbb{E}[\text{number of true pairs}] = 
\mathbb{E}[\text{Number of pairs observed}] \times \Pr(\text{a pair is true}).
$$
We have defined $\rho$ as the probability of selecting any individual from the population $N$. Therefore, if we assume a large population size, the probability of sampling both case $i$ and its true pair is equal to $\rho^2$. Under our first assumption---that case $i$ is linked by transmission to only one other case $j$---the total number of pairs in the population is equal to $\frac{N}{2}$. We also know that $\rho=\frac{M}{N}$, so the total number of true transmission pairs in the sample is:

\begin{equation}
    \mathbb{E}[\text{number of true pairs}] = \rho ^2 \times \frac{N}{2} = \rho ^2 \times \frac{1}{2}\frac{M}{\rho} = \frac{M}{2}\rho
    \label{eq:simple_truepairs}
\end{equation}

We know from Equation \ref{eq:simple_pr} the probability that an observed pair indicates a true transmission pairs, so we can divide the number of true pairs by this quantity to get the expected number of observed pairs:

\begin{align*}\label{eq:simple_obspairs}
    \mathbb{E}[\text{number of pairs observed}] 
    &= \frac{\mathbb{E}[\text{number of true pairs}]}{\Pr(\text{a pair is true})}\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{\frac{M}{2} \rho}{\rho/\big[\rho + (1-\chi^{M-1})(1-\rho)\big]}\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{M}{2} \big[\rho + (1-\chi^{M-1})(1-\rho)\big]
    \intertext{\textbf{Therefore, the expected number of pairs observed assuming perfect sensitivity, 
    single linkage, and single transmission is:}}
    \mathbb{E}[\text{number of pairs observed}] 
    &= \frac{M}{2} \big[\rho + (1-\chi^{M-1})(1-\rho)\big]
    \stepcounter{equation}\tag{\theequation}\\
\end{align*}

Under our simplifying assumptions, Equation \ref{eq:simple_obspairs} reveals two important principles:

\begin{itemize}
\item[1.] The quantity $\mathbb{E}[\text{number of pairs observed}]$ increases more rapidly than $\mathbb{E}[\text{number of true pairs}]$ as $M$ is increased. Therefore, the false discovery rate increases as $M$ increases, all else being equal.
\item[2.] Both quantities $\mathbb{E}[\text{number of pairs observed}]$ and $\Pr (y_{ij} \mid z_{ij})$ will be highly dependent on the value of $\chi$, the specificity of the linkage criteria.
\end{itemize}

\section{Relaxing perfect sensitivity}

\subsection{Assumptions}

In this section, we preserve the first two assumptions from Appendix \ref{section:simple} and relax our assumption of perfect sensitivity when case $i$ and its true transmission pair are both in the sample. Our remaining assumptions are:

\begin{itemize}
    \item[1.] Each case $i$ is linked by transmission to only one other case $j$ in the population (N).
    \item[2.] Each case $i$ is linked by the linkage criteria to only one other case $j$ in the sampled population (M).
\end{itemize}

\subsection{Derivation of the probability of transmission given linkage}

When perfect sensitivity is relaxed, we must account for both the uncertainty that the true pair of case $i$ is in sample $M$ and the uncertainty that we correctly identify this pairing when both cases are in the sample. Thus we rewrite Equation \ref{eq:simple_pr} with additional terms to account for the increased number of potential outcomes.

\begin{align*} \label{eq:singletrans_singlelink_pr}
    \Pr(\y \mid \z) &= \frac{\Pr(\y, \z)}{\Pr(\z)} = \frac{\Pr(\y, \z)}{\Pr(\y, \z) + \Pr(\neg\y, \z)}\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{
    \Pr(\y, \z\mid S_i)\Pr(S_i) + \cancelto{0}{\Pr(\y, \z\mid \neg S_i)}\Pr(\neg S_i)
    }{
    \begin{bmatrix}
    \Pr(\y, \z\mid S_i)\Pr(S_i) + \cancelto{0}{\Pr(\y, \z\mid \neg S_i)}\Pr(\neg S_i) \  + \\
    \Pr(\neg\y, \z\mid S_i)\Pr(S_i) + \Pr(\neg\y, \z\mid \neg S_i)\Pr(\neg S_i)
    \end{bmatrix}
    }\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{
    \Pr(\y, \z\mid S_i)\Pr(S_i)
    }{
    \Pr(\y, \z\mid S_i)\Pr(S_i) + \Pr(\neg\y, \z\mid S_i)\Pr(S_i) + \Pr(\neg\y, \z\mid \neg S_i)\Pr(\neg S_i)
    }\\[10pt]
    \intertext{The specificity of the linkage criteria (defined here as $\eta$) is the probability 
    that a link is correctly identified between case $i$ and its true infector when both are in the sample $M$,
    or $\Pr(\y, \z\mid S_i)$. Substituting this and the previously-defined $\Pr(S_i)=\rho$, we get:}
    &= \frac{
    \eta\rho
    }{
    \eta\rho + \Pr(\neg\y, \z\mid S_i)\rho + \Pr(\neg\y, \z\mid \neg S_i)(1-\rho).
    }\\[10pt]
    \intertext{We know that $\Pr(\neg\y, \z\mid S_i)$ is the probability that the true pair of case $i$ is in the sample $M$, but that it is linked by the linkage criteria to exactly one other sample $j$ that is not its true infector. In this instance, the linkage criteria must avoid inferring $M-2$ other incorrect links ($\Pr=1-\chi^{M-2}$) and as well as avoid inferring a link with the true infector of case $i$ ($\Pr=1-\eta$). Because in this derivation we again assume that each caseis linked to exactly one other, avoiding linkage with these other cases implies that case $i$ is linked to the remaining case in the sample (in this case, not its true pair). If the true pair of $i$ is not in the sample \big($\Pr(\neg\y, \z\mid \neg S_i)$\big), the probability of linking $i$ to one other sample that is not its true infector is simply $1-\chi^{M-1}$, as previously defined:}
    &= \frac{
    \eta\rho
    }{
    \eta\rho + (1-\chi^{M-2})(1-\eta)\rho + (1-\chi^{M-1})(1-\rho)
    }\\[10pt]
    \intertext{\textbf{Therefore, the probability of transmission given linkage 
    assuming single transmission and single linkage is:}}
    \Pr(\y \mid \z) &= \frac{
    \eta\rho
    }{
    \eta\rho + (1-\chi^{M-2})(1-\eta)\rho + (1-\chi^{M-1})(1-\rho)
    }
    \stepcounter{equation}\tag{\theequation}\\[10pt]
\end{align*}
The probability spaces in Equation \ref{eq:singletrans_singlelink_pr} above can also be represented by the conceptual diagram shown below:

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{../Figures/Fig1.png}
\end{center}

This derivation makes the implicit assumption that sensitivity is independent of both sample size and specificity ($M \perp \eta \perp \chi$). This is unlikely to be true in a real transmission scenario where case $i$ is closely related to multiple other cases, but allows us to approximate the probability an identified transmission link is true given our other assumptions.

\subsection{Calculating the expected number of pairs in the sample}
We now re-write Equation \ref{eq:simple_truepairs} with the sensitivity assumption relaxed:

\begin{equation}
    \mathbb{E}[\text{number of true pairs}] = \eta\rho ^2 \times \frac{N}{2} 
    = \eta\rho ^2 \times \frac{1}{2}\frac{M}{\rho} = \frac{M}{2}\eta\rho
\end{equation}

Where the probability that a pair is in the sample is still $\rho^2$ but we must include the probability of that pair being correctly linked by the linkage criteria, $\eta$. We can again calculate the expected number of pairs observed, this time incorporating $\eta$:

\begin{align*}\label{eq:singletrans_singlelink_obspairs}
    \mathbb{E}[\text{number of pairs observed}] 
    &= \frac{\mathbb{E}[\text{number of true pairs}]}{\Pr(\text{a pair is true})}\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{\frac{M}{2} \eta\rho}{\eta\rho/\big[\eta\rho +
    \rho(1-\eta)(1-\chi^{M-2}) + (1-\rho)(1-\chi ^{M-1})\big]}\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{M}{2} \big[\eta\rho + \rho(1-\eta)(1-\chi^{M-2}) + (1-\rho)(1-\chi ^{M-1})\big]\\[15pt]
    \intertext{\textbf{Therefore, the expected number of pairs observed, 
    assuming single linkage and single transmission is:}}
    \mathbb{E}[\text{number of pairs observed}] 
    &= \frac{M}{2} \big[\eta\rho + \rho(1-\eta)(1-\chi^{M-2}) + (1-\rho)(1-\chi ^{M-1})\big]
    \stepcounter{equation}\tag{\theequation}
\end{align*}

As before (see Equation \ref{eq:simple_obspairs}), when all other parameters are held constant, the false discovery rate will increase as the sample size $M$ increases because the number of observed pairs increases more rapidly than the number of true pairs. Further, with imperfect sensitivity, increasing the sample size $M$ has an even more substantial effect (due to an additional term containing 1-$\chi^M$) on the expected number of pairs observed than before, thus more quickly increasing the false discovery rate.

\section{Relaxing the assumption of single transmission pairs}

\subsection{Assumptions}

Thus far, we have assumed that every case $i$ has been connected by transmission to exactly one other case; in other words, that $i$ is either an infector or infectee, but not both. During an outbreak where a pathogen has a reproductive number $R$ of greater than $1$, it is likely that each infector will have multiple infectees. Therefore, we relax the single transmission assumption and calculate the probability of correctly identifying a true link given that $i$ has transmitted to $R$ other individuals in the population. However, we maintain that each individual has been infected by exactly one other individual, i.e., that multiple infections are not possible. Therefore, each case $i$ has on average $R+1$ true links, and we define $k$ as the number of these true links of case $i$ that are in the sample $M$.

As a result, we remain with just one of our original assumptions:

\begin{itemize}
    \item[1.] Each case $i$ is linked by the linkage criteria to only one other case $j$ 
    in the sampled population (M).
\end{itemize}

\subsection{Derivation of the probability of transmission given linkage}
\label{subsec:singlelink}

\textit{Derivation for a given value of} k

If there are $k$ individuals in sample $M$ that are truly linked with case $i$, then the probability of true transmission linkage given the outcome of the linkage criteria and number of links $k$ is:

\begin{align*} \label{eq:singlelink_pr_k}
    \Pr(\y \mid \z, k) &= \frac{\Pr(\y, \z, k)}{\Pr(\z, k)}\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{\Pr(\y, \z, k)}{\Pr(\y, \z, k) + \Pr(\neg\y, \z, k)}\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{\Pr(\y, \z \mid k)\Pr(k)}{\Pr(\y, \z \mid k)\Pr(k) + \Pr(\neg\y, \z \mid k)\Pr(k)}\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{\Pr(\y, \z \mid k)}{\Pr(\y, \z \mid k) + \Pr(\neg\y, \z \mid k)}\\[10pt]
    \intertext{We can show that is the probability that case $i$ is not linked any of its $k$
    true links is $(1-\eta)^k$, so the probability that case $i$ is linked to at least one of 
    its $k$ true links in the sample is $1-(1-\eta)^k$. Because we still assume that the linkage
    criteria will identify exactly one link for each case $i$, this is equivalent to the 
    probability $\Pr(\y, \z \mid k)$:}
    &= \frac{[1-(1-\eta)^k]}{[1-(1-\eta)^k]+\Pr(\neg\y, \z \mid k)}\\[10pt]
    \intertext{Similarly, the probability that case $i$ is incorrectly linked to another case
    is the probability it is not linked to any of its true infectees ($(1-\eta)^k$) times the
    probability of not linking to any of the other incorrect links ($1-\chi^{M-1-k}$):}
    &= \frac{[1-(1-\eta)^k]}{[1-(1-\eta)^k]+(1-\eta)^k(1-\chi^{M-1-k})}\\[15pt]
    \intertext{\textbf{Therefore, the probability of transmission given linkage 
    assuming single linkage is:}}
    \Pr(\y \mid \z) &= \frac{[1-(1-\eta)^k]}{[1-(1-\eta)^k]+(1-\eta)^k(1-\chi^{M-1-k})}
    \stepcounter{equation}\tag{\theequation}\\[10pt]
\end{align*}

\textit{Derivation for all possible values of $k$}

We can extend Equation \ref{eq:singlelink_pr_k} to include all possible values of $k$ for a given case $i$:

\begin{equation} 
    \begin{aligned}\label{eq:singlelink_pr_sum}
    \Pr(y_{ij} \mid z_{ij}) &= \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Pr(y_{ij} \mid z_{ij}, k)\Pr(k \mid z_{ij})\\[10pt]
    &= \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Pr(y_{ij} \mid z_{ij},k)\frac{\Pr(z_{ij} \mid k)\Pr(k)}{\Pr(z_{ij})}\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{1}{\Pr(z_{ij})}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Pr(y_{ij} \mid z_{ij},k)\Pr(z_{ij} \mid k)\Pr(k)\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{1}{\Pr(z_{ij})}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Pr(y_{ij}, z_{ij} \mid k)\Pr(k)\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{1}{\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\Pr(z_{ij} \mid k)\Pr(k)}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} 
    \Pr(y_{ij}, z_{ij} \mid k)\Pr(k)\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{1}{\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}[\Pr(y_{ij}, z_{ij} \mid k) + 
    \Pr(\neg y_{ij}, z_{ij} \mid k)]\Pr(k)}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Pr(y_{ij}, z_{ij} \mid k)\Pr(k)\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Pr(k)\Pr(y_{ij}, z_{ij} \mid k)}
    {\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\Pr(k)[\Pr(y_{ij}, z_{ij} \mid k) + \Pr(\neg y_{ij}, z_{ij} \mid k)]}\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Pr(k)(1-(1-\eta)^k)}{\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\Pr(k)[(1-(1-\eta)^k) +
    (1-\eta)^k(1-\chi^{M-1-k})]}\\
    \end{aligned}
\end{equation}

As a check on the formulation of Equation \ref{eq:singlelink_pr_sum}, let there be only one true transmission link for case $i$. In this instance, $k=1$ occurs with probability $\rho$ (the probability that this single link is in the sample) and $k=0$ with probability $1-\rho$:

\begin{equation}
    \begin{aligned}
    \Pr(y_{ij} \mid z_{ij}) &=
    \frac{
    \sum_{k=0}^{1} \Pr(k)(1-(1-\eta)^k)
    }{
    \sum_{k=0}^{1}\Pr(k)[(1-(1-\eta)^k) + (1-\eta)^k(1-\chi^{M-1-k})]
    }\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{
    [(1-\rho)\cancelto{0}{(1-(1-\eta)^0)}+\rho(1-(1-\eta)^1]
    }{
    \begin{bmatrix}
    (1-\rho)[\cancelto{0}{(1-(1-\eta)^0)} + \cancelto{1}{(1-\eta)^0}(1-\chi^{M-1-0})] \ + \\
    \rho[(1-(1-\eta)^1) + (1-\eta)^1(1-\chi^{M-1-1})]
    \end{bmatrix}
    }\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{\eta\rho}{
    (1-\rho)(1-\chi^{M-1}) +
    \eta\rho + \rho(1-\eta)(1-\chi^{M-2})
    }\\
    \end{aligned}
\end{equation}

This result is equivalent to Equation \ref{eq:singletrans_singlelink_pr} above, which was also derived under the assumption that each case $i$ is truly linked by transmission to exactly one other case.

\textbf{Therefore, we can conclude that the probability of transmission given linkage, 
assuming single linkage and for all possible values of $k$ transmission links in the sample, is:}

\begin{equation}
 \Pr(y_{ij} \mid z_{ij}) = \frac{\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Pr(k)(1-(1-\eta)^k)}
 {\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\Pr(k)[(1-(1-\eta)^k) + (1-\eta)^k(1-\chi^{M-1-k})]}
\end{equation}

\textit{Derivation if $k$ is poisson-distributed}

In an infectious disease outbreak, it may be difficult or impossible to know the true number of transmission links in the sample ($k$) for any given case. Therefore, we use the population average for the number of secondary cases, which we define here are $R_{pop}$. Note that we use $R_{pop}$ instead of the traditional $R_e$ because $R_e$ has a specific meaning with regards to disease susceptibility in the population, and here we mean the average number of secondary cases of each case in a finite population. As discussed in the main text, in practice $R_{pop}$ is always less than one.

We draw $k$ from a Poisson distribution with mean $\lambda = \rho(R_{pop} + 1)$. Here, $R_{pop}+1$ is the total number of transmission links for a given sample $i$; we add one because case $i$ is linked to the $R_{pop}$ individuals he/she infects as well as to his/her infector (note that multiple infections are not allowed under the assumption that each case is infected by exactly one individual). We multiply by $\rho$ to account for the probability that each of these true transmission links is actually observed in the sample.

We incorporate the Poisson representation of the number of true transmission links in the sample with the Poisson probability density function:

\begin{equation}
\Pr(k \mid \lambda) = \lambda^k e^{-\lambda} \frac{1}{k!}.
\end{equation}

Returning to the result of the derivation in Equation \ref{eq:singlelink_pr_sum}, we now have:
\begin{align*}
    &\Pr(y_{ij} \mid z_{ij}) =\\[10pt]
    &= 
    \frac{\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Pr(k \mid \lambda)(1-(1-\eta)^k)
    }{
    \sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\Pr(k \mid \lambda)[(1-(1-\eta)^k) + (1-\eta)^k(1-\chi^{M-1-k})]
    }\\[10pt]
    &=
    \frac{
    \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \lambda^k e^{-\lambda} \frac{1}{k!} (1-(1-\eta)^k)
    }{
    \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \lambda^k e^{-\lambda} \frac{1}{k!}[(1-(1-\eta)^k) + (1-\eta)^k(1-\chi^{M-1-k})]
    }\\[10pt]
    &=
    \frac{
    \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[ \lambda^k e^{-\lambda} \frac{1}{k!} \Big] - 
    \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[\lambda^k e^{-\lambda} \frac{1}{k!} (1-\eta)^k \Big]
    }{
    \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[ \lambda^k e^{-\lambda} \frac{1}{k!} \Big] - 
    \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[\lambda^k e^{-\lambda} \frac{1}{k!} (1-\eta)^k \Big] + 
    \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[\lambda^k e^{-\lambda} \frac{1}{k!} (1-\eta)^k (1-\chi^{M-1-k}) \Big]
    }\\
    \intertext{we know that $\Big[ \lambda^k e^{-\lambda} \frac{1}{k!} \Big]$ is the 
    probability density function of a Poisson distribution with mean $\lambda$, 
    therefore the sum of this expression over all values of $k$ is, by definition, equal to one.}
    &=
    \frac{
    1 - \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[\lambda^k e^{-\lambda} \frac{1}{k!} (1-\eta)^k \Big]
    }{
    1 - \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[\lambda^k e^{-\lambda} \frac{1}{k!} (1-\eta)^k \Big] + 
    \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[\lambda^k e^{-\lambda} \frac{1}{k!} (1-\eta)^k (1-\chi^{M-1-k}) \Big]
    }\\[10pt]
    &=
    \frac{
    1 - \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[\lambda^k e^{-\lambda} \frac{1}{k!} (1-\eta)^k \Big]
    }{
    1 - \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[\lambda^k e^{-\lambda} \frac{1}{k!} (1-\eta)^k \Big] + 
    \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[\lambda^k e^{-\lambda} \frac{1}{k!} (1-\eta)^k \Big] - 
    \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[\lambda^k e^{-\lambda} \frac{1}{k!} (1-\eta)^k (\chi^{M-1-k}) \Big]
    }\\[10pt]
    &=
    \frac{
    1 - \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[\lambda^k e^{-\lambda} \frac{1}{k!} (1-\eta)^k \Big]
    }{
    1 - \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[\lambda^k e^{-\lambda} \frac{1}{k!} (1-\eta)^k (\chi^{M-1-k}) \Big]
    }\\[10pt]
    \intertext{we now move terms not dependent on $k$ out of the summation:}
    &=
    \frac{
    1 - e^{-\lambda} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[\lambda^k \frac{1}{k!} (1-\eta)^k \Big]
    }{
    1 - e^{-\lambda}\chi^{M-1}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[\lambda^k \frac{1}{k!} (1-\eta)^k \chi^{-k} \Big]
    }\\[10pt]
    \intertext{and combine terms raised to exponent $k$:}
    &=
    \frac{
    1 - e^{-\lambda}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[(\lambda(1-\eta))^k  \frac{1}{k!} \Big]
    }{
    1 - e^{-\lambda}\chi^{M-1}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[\Big(\frac{\lambda (1-\eta)}{\chi}\Big)^k \frac{1}{k!} \Big]
    }\\[10pt]
    \intertext{We now multiply the summation in the numerator by one, using terms such that
    we arrive at a new specification of the Poisson probability density function,
    this time with the rate parameter redefined as $\lambda(1-\eta)$:}
    &=
    \frac{
    1 - e^{-\lambda}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[(\lambda(1-\eta))^k \frac{1}{k!} 
    \Big(\frac{e^{-\lambda(1-\eta)}}{e^{-\lambda(1-\eta)}}\Big) \Big]
    }{
    1 - e^{-\lambda}\chi^{M-1}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[\Big(\frac{\lambda (1-\eta)}{\chi}\Big)^k \frac{1}{k!} \Big]
    }\\[10pt]
    &=
    \frac{
    1 - \frac{e^{-\lambda}}{e^{-\lambda(1-\eta)}}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} 
    \Big[(\lambda(1-\eta))^k \Big(e^{-\lambda(1-\eta)}\Big) \frac{1}{k!} \Big]
    }{
    1 - e^{-\lambda}\chi^{M-1}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[\Big(\frac{\lambda (1-\eta)}{\chi}\Big)^k \frac{1}{k!} \Big]
    }\\[10pt]
    \intertext{We now repeat this process in the denominator, but with a rate parameter of $\lambda(1-\eta)/\chi$:}
    &=
    \frac{
    1 - \frac{e^{-\lambda}}{e^{-\lambda(1-\eta)}}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[(\lambda(1-\eta))^k
    \Big(e^{-\lambda(1-\eta)}\Big) \frac{1}{k!} \Big]
    }{
    1 - e^{-\lambda}\chi^{M-1}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[\Big(\frac{\lambda (1-\eta)}{\chi}\Big)^k \frac{1}{k!}
    \Big(\frac{e^{-\lambda(1-\eta)/\chi}}{e^{-\lambda(1-\eta)/\chi}}\Big) \Big]
    }\\[10pt]
    &=
    \frac{
    1 - \frac{e^{-\lambda}}{e^{-\lambda(1-\eta)}}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Big[(\lambda(1-\eta))^k
    \Big(e^{-\lambda(1-\eta)}\Big) \frac{1}{k!} \Big]
    }{
    1 - \frac{e^{-\lambda}\chi^{M-1}}{e^{-\lambda(1-\eta)/\chi}} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} 
    \Big[\Big(\frac{\lambda (1-\eta)}{\chi}\Big)^k \Big(e^{-\lambda(1-\eta)/\chi} \Big) \frac{1}{k!} \Big]
    }\\[10pt]
    &=
    \frac{
    1 - \frac{e^{-\lambda}}{e^{-\lambda(1-\eta)}}
    }{
    1 - \frac{e^{-\lambda}\chi^{M-1}}{e^{-\lambda(1-\eta)/\chi}}
    }\\[10pt]
    &=
    \frac{
    1 - e^{-\lambda+\lambda-\lambda\eta}
    }{
    1 - (\chi^{M-1}) e^{-\lambda+\frac{\lambda}{\chi}-\frac{\lambda\eta}{\chi}}
    }\\[10pt]
    &=
    \frac{
    1 - e^{-\lambda\eta}
    }{
    1 - (\chi^{M-1}) e^{\lambda(\frac{1-\eta}{\chi}-1)}
    }\\[10pt]
    \intertext{Finally, we rewrite $\lambda$ in terms of the sampling fraction ($\rho$) 
    and $R_{pop}$ as defined above, where $\lambda = \rho(R_{pop}+1)$:}
    &=
    \frac{
    1 - e^{-\rho(R_{pop}+1)\eta}
    }{
    1 - (\chi^{M-1}) e^{\rho(R_{pop}+1)(\frac{1-\eta}{\chi}-1)}
    }\\[10pt]%\stepcounter{equation}\tag{\theequation}\label{eq:pois_k}
\end{align*}

As a check on the formulation in the equation above, let $\chi$ equal one, indicating perfect specificity of the linkage criteria:

\begin{equation}
    \Pr(y_{ij} \mid z_{ij})
    = \frac{
    1 - e^{-\rho(R_{pop}+1)\eta}
    }{
    1 - (\chi^{M-1}) e^{\rho(R_{pop}+1)(\frac{1-\eta}{1}-1)}
    }
    = \frac{
    1 - e^{-\rho(R_{pop}+1)\eta}
    }{
    1 - e^{-\rho(R_{pop}+1)\eta}
    }
    = 1
\end{equation}

The equation above shows that---given our assumptions that the linkage criteria will only identify one link for any sample and perfect sensitivity---any identified link will be correct. This is because all negative links will be correctly avoided by definition of perfect specificity, leaving only true infectors as possible links.

\textbf{Therefore, we can conclude that the probability of transmission given linkage, 
assuming single linkage and assuming $k$ is poisson-distributed, is:}

\begin{equation}\label{eq:singlelink_pois_k}
 \Pr(y_{ij} \mid z_{ij}) = \frac{
    1 - e^{-\rho(R_{pop}+1)\eta}
    }{
    1 - (\chi^{M-1}) e^{\rho(R_{pop}+1)(\frac{1-\eta}{\chi}-1)}
    }
\end{equation}

\subsection{Calculating the expected number of pairs in the sample}
\label{subsec:singlelink_pairs}

To calculate the expected number of pairs in the sample under the current assumptions, we start by defining the vector $k_i$, which gives the number of true pairs of case $i$ in a sample of size $M$ (note that this includes the infector of case $i$, as well us any infectees). We then define $K$ as the summation of $k_i$ over all $i$ cases in the sample of size $M$:
$$ K = \sum_{i=1}^{M}{k_i} $$

Therefore, the total number of true pairs in the sample is $\frac{K}{2}$, where $K$ is divided by two because by definition each pair will be counted exactly twice (as part of $k$ pairs of the infector and the $k$ pairs of the infectee). Accounting for the probability that a true transmission pair is identified as true by the linkage criteria $\eta$, the expected number of true pairs in the sample is:
$$ \mathbb{E}[\text{number of true pairs}] = \mathbb{E}\bigg[\frac{K\eta}{2}\bigg] = \frac{\eta}{2}\times\mathbb{E}[K].$$

Under our assumption that each $k$ is Poisson distributed with rate $\lambda = \rho(R_{pop}+1)$, the sum of all $k$ is also Poisson distributed with rate $M\times\lambda$.
$$ K \sim {\rm Poisson}\big(M\rho(R_{pop}+1)\big) $$

Since the expected value of a Poisson distributed discrete random variable is simply the rate $\lambda$, $M\rho(R_{pop}+1)$ substitutes for $K$ in the expected number of true pairs.
$$ \mathbb{E}[\text{number of true pairs}] = \frac{\eta}{2}\times\mathbb{E}[K] = \frac{M\rho(R_{pop}+1)\eta}{2}$$

We can then use this to calculate the expected number of observed pairs in the sample, substituting Equation \ref{eq:singlelink_pois_k} for the probability a pair is true:

\begin{align*}
    \mathbb{E}[\text{number of pairs observed}] &= \frac{\mathbb{E}[\text{number of true
    pairs}]}{\Pr(\text{a pair is true})}\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{
    \big[ \frac{M\rho(R_{pop}+1)\eta}{2} \big]
    }{
    \bigg[ \frac{
    1 - e^{-\rho(R_{pop}+1)\eta}
    }{
    1 - (\chi^{M-1}) e^{\rho(R_{pop}+1)(\frac{1-\eta}{\chi}-1)}
    } \bigg]
    }\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{
    \big(M\rho (R_{pop}+1)\eta\big)\big(1-(\chi^{M-1})e^{\rho(R_{pop}+1)(\frac{1-\eta}{\chi}-1})\big)
    }{
    2\big(1-e^{-\rho(R_{pop}+1)\eta}\big)
    }\\[10pt]
    \intertext{\textbf{Therefore, the expected number of pairs observed, assuming that the 
    number of transmission links of any case $i$ is Poisson-distributed and single linkage, is:}}
    \mathbb{E}[\text{number of pairs observed}] &= \frac{M}{2}\Big[\frac{
    \eta\rho (R_{pop}+1)\big(1-(\chi^{M-1})e^{\rho(R_{pop}+1)(\frac{1-\eta}{\chi}-1})\big)
    }{
    1-e^{-\rho(R_{pop}+1)\eta}
    }\Big]
    \stepcounter{equation}\tag{\theequation}
\end{align*}

\section{Final derivation: multiple transmissions and multiple links}

\subsection{Assumptions}

Here we relax the final assumption that the linkage case only identifies pairs of samples, and allow the linkage criteria to identify multiple links of case $i$. We do, however, assume that linkage events are independent of one another, i.e. linkage of case $i$ to case $j$ has no bearing on linkage of case $i$ to any other sample.

\subsection{Derivation of the probability of transmission given linkage}

\textit{Derivation for a given value of $k$}

We begin as we did in section \ref{subsec:singlelink}, by deriving the probability of transmission for a given value of $k$, where $k$ is the number of cases in the sample $M$ that are truly linked with case $i$.

\begin{align*} \label{eq:final_pr_k}
    \Pr(\y \mid \z, k) &= \frac{\Pr(\y, \z, k)}{\Pr(\z, k)}\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{\Pr(\y, \z, k)}{\Pr(\y, \z, k) + \Pr(\neg\y, \z, k)}\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{\Pr(\y, \z \mid k)\Pr(k)}{\Pr(\y, \z \mid k)\Pr(k) + \Pr(\neg\y, \z \mid k)\Pr(k)}\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{\Pr(\y, \z \mid k)}{\Pr(\y, \z \mid k) + \Pr(\neg\y, \z \mid k)}\\[10pt]
    \intertext{Without the single linkage assumption, the probability $\Pr(\y, \z \mid k)$ 
    is no longer simply 1 minus the probability of not linking to any true links. 
    Therefore, we continue the derivation by applying Bayes rule and the law of total probability to each term:}
    &= \frac{\Pr(z_{ij} \mid y_{ij}, k)\Pr(y_{ij} \mid k)}{\Pr(z_{ij} \mid y_{ij}, k)
    \Pr(y_{ij} \mid k)+\Pr(z_{ij} \mid \neg y_{ij}, k)\Pr(\neg y_{ij} \mid k)}\\[10pt]
    \intertext{Given our assumption of independence, the probability that the linkage criteria 
    correctly links cases $i$ and $j$ (i.e., $\Pr(z_{ij} \mid y_{ij}, k)$ is the sensitivity 
    of the linkage criteria, or $\eta$. And the probability that $i$ infected $j$ (or vice versa) 
    is simply the number of true links of case $i$ ($k$) in the sample, over the total number of other cases 
    in the sample ($M-1$):}
    &= \frac{\eta \frac{k}{M-1}}{\eta \frac{k}{M-1}+\Pr(z_{ij} \mid \neg y_{ij}, k)\Pr(\neg y_{ij} \mid k)}\\[10pt]
    \intertext{Similarly, the probability of linking cases $i$ and $j$ given that they are not 
    a true transmission pair is simply the false positive rate, or ($1-\chi$). 
    And the probability that $i$ and $j$ did not infect one another is the number of cases 
    not connected to case $i$ ($M-k-1)$ over the number of other cases in the sample ($M-1)$:}
    &= \frac{\eta \frac{k}{M-1}}{\eta \frac{k}{M-1}+(1-\chi) \frac{M-k-1}{M-1}}\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{\eta k}{\eta k + (1-\chi)(M-k-1)}\\[15pt]
    \intertext{\textbf{Therefore, the probability of transmission given linkage for a given value of k is:}}
    \Pr(\y \mid \z) &= 
    \frac{\eta k}{\eta k + (1-\chi)(M-k-1)}
    \stepcounter{equation}\tag{\theequation}\\[10pt]
\end{align*}

\textit{Derivation for all possible values of $k$}

We can extend Equation \ref{eq:final_pr_k} to include all possibilities of $k$ for a given case $i$, again starting as in the previous section:

\begin{align*} \label{eq:final_pr_sum}
    \Pr(y_{ij} \mid z_{ij}) &= \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Pr(y_{ij} \mid z_{ij}, k)\Pr(k \mid z_{ij})\\[10pt]
    &= \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Pr(y_{ij} \mid z_{ij},k)\frac{\Pr(z_{ij} \mid k)\Pr(k)}{\Pr(z_{ij})}\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{1}{\Pr(z_{ij})}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Pr(y_{ij} \mid z_{ij},k)\Pr(z_{ij} \mid k)\Pr(k)\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{1}{\Pr(z_{ij})}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Pr(y_{ij}, z_{ij} \mid k)\Pr(k)\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{1}{\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\Pr(z_{ij} \mid k)\Pr(k)}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} 
    \Pr(y_{ij}, z_{ij} \mid k)\Pr(k)\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{1}{\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}[\Pr(y_{ij}, z_{ij} \mid k) + 
    \Pr(\neg y_{ij}, z_{ij} \mid k)]\Pr(k)}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Pr(y_{ij}, z_{ij} \mid k)\Pr(k)\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Pr(k)\Pr(y_{ij}, z_{ij} \mid k)}
    {\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\Pr(k)[\Pr(y_{ij}, z_{ij} \mid k) + \Pr(\neg y_{ij}, z_{ij} \mid k)]}\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Pr(k)\eta k}
    {\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\Pr(k)[\eta k + (1-\chi)(M-k-1)]}\\[15pt]
    \intertext{\textbf{Therefore, the probability of transmission given linkage for all 
    possible values of $k$ transmission links in the sample is:}}
    \Pr(y_{ij} \mid z_{ij}) &= \frac{\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Pr(k)\eta k}
    {\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\Pr(k)[\eta k + (1-\chi)(M-k-1)]}
    \stepcounter{equation}\tag{\theequation}\\[10pt]
\end{align*}

\textit{Derivation if $k$ is poisson-distributed}

As in the previous section, we calculate the probability of transmission assuming $k$ is poisson-distributed with mean $\lambda = \rho (R+1)$:

\begin{align*} \label{eq:final_pois}
    \Pr(y_{ij} \mid z_{ij}) &= \frac{\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Pr(k)\eta k}
    {\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\Pr(k)[\eta k + (1-\chi)(M-k-1)]}\\[10pt]
    \intertext{We then pull all terms not containing $k$ out of the sums and 
    expand out all additions and subtractions:}
    &= \frac{\eta \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \Pr(k) k}
    {\eta \sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\Pr(k) k +
    (1-\chi)[M\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\Pr(k) - \sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\Pr(k)k - \sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\Pr(k)]}\\[10pt]
    \intertext{We know that the sum of a random variable times the probability of that variable 
    is equal to the expectation of that variable, i.e. $\mathbb{E}[k]=\sum \Pr(k)k$, and that the sum of the probability of a random variable is equal to one:}
    &= \frac{\eta \mathbb{E}[k]}
    {\eta \mathbb{E}[k] +
    (1-\chi)(M - \mathbb{E}[k]-1)}\\[10pt]
    \intertext{We also know that the expectation of a Poisson-distributed variable is 
    equal to the rate parameter, $\lambda$:}
    &= \frac{\eta \lambda}
    {\eta \lambda + (1-\chi)(M - \lambda - 1)}\\[10pt]
    \intertext{Finally, we rewrite $\lambda$ in terms of the sampling fraction ($\rho$) 
    and the effective reproductive number ($R_{pop}$) as defined above, where $\lambda = \rho (R_{pop}+1)$:}
    &= \frac{\eta \rho (R_{pop}+1)}
    {\eta \rho (R_{pop}+1) + (1-\chi)(M - \rho (R_{pop}+1) - 1)}\\[10pt]
    \intertext{\textbf{Therefore, we can conclude that the probability of transmission 
    given linkage assuming $k$ is Poisson-distributed is:}}
    \Pr(y_{ij} \mid z_{ij}) &= \frac{\eta \rho (R_{pop}+1)}
    {\eta \rho (R_{pop}+1) + (1-\chi)(M - \rho (R_{pop}+1) - 1)}\\
    \stepcounter{equation}\tag{\theequation}\\[10pt]
\end{align*}

\subsubsection{Calculating the expected number of pairs in the sample}

To calculate the expected number of pairs in the sample allowing for multiple transmissions and multiple linkages, we start, as in section \ref{subsec:singlelink_pairs} by defining $K$ as the summation of $k_i$ over all $i$ cases in the sample of size $M$:
$$ K = \sum_{i=1}^{M}{k_i} $$

Therefore, the total number of true pairs in the sample is $\frac{K}{2}$ and the expected number of true pairs in the sample is:
$$ \mathbb{E}[\text{number of true pairs}] = \mathbb{E}\bigg[\frac{K\eta}{2}\bigg] = \frac{\eta}{2}\times\mathbb{E}[K].$$

Under our assumption that each $k$ is Poisson distributed with rate $\lambda = \rho(R_{pop}+1)$, the sum of all $k$ is also Poisson distributed with rate $M\times\lambda$. Therefore, $\mathbb{E}[K] = M \times \lambda = M\rho(R_{pop}+1)$:

$$ \mathbb{E}[\text{number of true pairs}] = \frac{\eta}{2}\times\mathbb{E}[K] = \frac{M\rho(R_{pop}+1)\eta}{2}$$

We can then use this to calculate the expected number of observed pairs in the sample, substituting Equation \ref{eq:final_pois} for the probability a pair is true:

\begin{align*}
    \mathbb{E}[\text{number of pairs observed}] &= \frac{\mathbb{E}[\text{number of true
    pairs}]}{\Pr(\text{a pair is true})}\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{
    \big[ \frac{M\rho(R_{pop}+1)\eta}{2} \big]
    }{
    \bigg[ \frac{\eta \rho (R_{pop}+1)}
    {\eta \rho (R_{pop}R+1) + (1-\chi)(M - \rho (R_{pop}+1) - 1)}\bigg]
    }\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{
    \big[M\rho (R_{pop}+1)\eta][\eta\rho (R_{pop}+1)+(1-\chi)(M-\rho (R_{pop}+1) - 1)\big]
    }{
    2\eta\rho (R_{pop}+1)
    }\\[10pt]
    &= \frac{M}{2}\big[\eta\rho (R_{pop}+1) + (1-\chi)(M-\rho (R_{pop}+1) - 1)\big]\\[10pt]
    \intertext{\textbf{Therefore, the expected number of pairs observed assuming that the 
    number of transmission links of any case $i$ is Poisson-distributed is:}}
    \mathbb{E}[\text{number of pairs observed}] &= \frac{M}{2}\big[\eta\rho (R_{pop}+1) + (1-\chi)(M-\rho (R_{pop}+1) - 1)\big]
    \stepcounter{equation}\tag{\theequation}
\end{align*}
